s.text: John Hellmann, a professor of English at Ohio State University, has little interest in the debate over Kennedy's character.
His broad smile, neither purely romantic nor wholly cynical, tells the story: This is a man who breaks the rules and is attractive, wealthy, and smart enough to get away with it.
His broad smile, neither purely romantic nor wholly cynical, tells the story: This is a man who breaks the rules and is attractive, wealthy, and smart enough to get away with it.
His broad smile, neither purely romantic nor wholly cynical, tells the story: This is a man who breaks the rules and is attractive, wealthy, and smart enough to get away with it.
His broad smile, neither purely romantic nor wholly cynical, tells the story: This is a man who breaks the rules and is attractive, wealthy, and smart enough to get away with it.

Whatever goings-on are going on in the executive mansion of the White House, Kennedy's brilliant Cabinet Room performance underscores his ability to "compartmentalize his life," as Hersh nicely puts it in his first chapter (before denying it in the rest of his book).
Hellmann's focus is instead on the Kennedy "image" and its importance to the man's historical reputation.
Hellmann sees no distinction between Kennedy's image and his actual achievement; for Hellmann, the image is the achievement.
In reading these books, Hellmann claims, Kennedy was shrewdly incorporating the archetypes--the lonely hero, the sensitive rebel--that would later compose his public persona.
Reckless at play, reckless at work, JFK is just a bad man with a nice smile that made travesties appear to be triumphs.
